question_details.query: What are the effects on butterfly and moth communities of opening up forest canopies through clearing, coppicing, or thinning?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, opening forest canopies by clearing, coppicing, or thinning commonly increased butterfly richness and/or abundance, while macro-moths often declined relative to closed or mature forest. Cleared patches had higher butterfly species richness than unmanaged or closed-canopy areas, but lower moth richness; larger clearings supported higher butterfly richness and abundance than undisturbed forest, and wider rides had lower macro-moth abundance than standard-width rides or mature forest; butterfly richness and abundance sometimes declined over the first three years post-clearance, and some species’ abundance peaked 2–4 years after clearance (3938). Thinning (often alongside prescribed burning, mulching, or nearby felling) increased butterfly richness and abundance within 1–4 years compared to unmanaged woodland or before management, while a thinned forest had similar fruit-feeding butterfly richness and abundance to an unmanaged regenerating forest, and partially cleared plots showed higher butterfly but lower moth richness than closed-canopy plots (3940). Coppiced woodland supported different moth and butterfly communities than mature forest; butterfly richness and abundance were higher in coppiced than unmanaged woodland and tended to be greater in more recently coppiced stands (e.g., 2–7 or 12–15 years since cutting) than in older (>15 years) stands; macro-moths had lower richness and abundance in coppiced than in mature forest and did not vary consistently with coppice age (3939).
summary_statements: Opening forest canopies by clearing, coppicing, or thinning commonly increased butterfly richness and/or abundance.
Macro-moths often declined relative to closed or mature forest when canopies were opened.
Cleared patches had higher butterfly species richness than unmanaged or closed-canopy areas.
Cleared patches had lower moth richness than unmanaged or closed-canopy areas.
Larger clearings supported higher butterfly richness and abundance than undisturbed forest.
Wider rides had lower macro-moth abundance than standard-width rides or mature forest.
Butterfly richness and abundance sometimes declined over the first three years post-clearance.
The abundance of some species peaked two to four years after clearance.

A thinned forest had similar fruit-feeding butterfly richness and abundance to an unmanaged regenerating forest.
Partially cleared plots showed higher butterfly richness than closed-canopy plots.
Partially cleared plots showed lower moth richness than closed-canopy plots.

question_details.query: How does rotational burning compare to leaving unburned patches during prescribed fires for butterfly populations in US prairies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from US prairies and similar open habitats shows that leaving unburned patches during prescribed fires was associated with increases in Karner blue butterfly abundance over 2–3 years, greater abundance for six of nine specialist species (with one lower and two similar), and confirmed use of all surveyed unburned patches by Karner blues [3879]. In contrast, rotational burning produced mixed outcomes: butterfly richness and/or abundance were sometimes higher than on unmanaged or annually burned sites, but often varied with time since last burn (generally higher more than 1–4 years after burning), and some taxa or regions showed lower abundance under rotational burning than under other management or unmanaged conditions; specific results included similar Karner blue abundance to unmanaged sites, variable responses among fritillaries (including lower abundance for some species in some regions), and patterns where regal fritillary abundance was higher in prairies managed on a three-year rotation or four years post-burn than in more recently or much longer unburned sites [3883].

question_details.query: What actions are available to mitigate the negative impacts of artificial lighting on moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Identified actions include: using warmer (red/yellow) lighting rather than other colours, for which five studies (Germany, Netherlands, Slovenia, UK) reported behavioural effects on moths, with fewer individuals and species attracted to yellow, green, white, or red lights (one case also at lower intensity) than to UV, actinic, blue, or conventional metal halide lights; and one study found four moth species spent more time feeding under red lights than under white or green lights, but less than in darkness [3906]. Other proposed actions for butterflies and moths currently have no studies evaluating effects: restricting use of polarized light [3903]; restricting timing of lighting to conserve natural light regimes [3901]; using glazing treatments to reduce light spill from inside lit buildings [3905]; and removing or changing turbine lighting to reduce insect attraction [3843].

question_details.query: What does the evidence say about the long-term success of re-establishing butterfly populations through translocation or captive-release?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 16 studies of translocations within former range, many translocated butterfly and moth populations persisted 2–12 years and increased in abundance, though some persisted 1–49 years and colonized new sites while others died out within 0–7 years; one review found 25% of translocated/released captive-bred populations survived ≥3 years, 38% died out within three years, and only 8% were known to survive >10 years; another review reported large copper populations survived up to 38 years but ultimately died out or required further releases; in specific cases, survival of translocated large copper caterpillars exceeded that of released captive-bred caterpillars, large blue caterpillar survival was higher when placed in ant nests without queens, and 19 years after translocation large blue genetic diversity matched the source population [3909]. Across 13 studies of captive-bred releases, several populations released as eggs, caterpillars, pupae or adults persisted 2–28 years and increased, sometimes with continued rearing or supplementation, but other releases died out after 1, 2 or 12 years or required further releases; a replicated study found 3/10 barberry carpet moth releases established with at least one persisting five years; a review across the UK and Ireland reported 25% of captive-bred/translocated populations survived >3 years, 38% died within that time, and only 8% were known to survive >10 years; released captive-bred large copper caterpillars had lower survival than captive, wild or translocated caterpillars [3914].

question_details.query: What actions can be taken in urban environments to support butterfly and moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Protect greenfield or undeveloped urban sites: In Singapore and Mexico, protected native forest and grassland in urban areas had higher butterfly species richness than urban parks or non-native Eucalyptus plantations [3836].
- Stop using pesticides in flower beds and greenspaces: In France, gardens without insecticides and herbicides had higher butterfly abundance, while gardens without fungicides and snail pellets had lower butterfly abundance [3900].
- Stop using herbicides on pavements and road verges: In the USA, restored roadside prairies with restricted herbicide application had greater butterfly species richness and abundance and lower mortality risk than verges dominated by non-native vegetation with no restrictions; in Canada, unsprayed and unmown transmission lines had similar butterfly species richness and total abundance to sprayed and mown lines, but higher abundance of northern pearl crescent and pearl crescent [3899].
- Plant parks, gardens and road verges with appropriate native species: Across studies in the USA and Germany, several found higher species richness of adult butterflies and moths and higher abundance of caterpillars in gardens and verges planted with native species compared to mixed or non-native plantings, though some studies found similar richness or abundance between native and non-native plantings; taller native milkweed species supported higher monarch egg and caterpillar abundance than shorter species; survival outcomes varied by species and setting, and caterpillar growth was similar across eight native milkweed species; adults used some native host plants in gardens more or less than in natural sites depending on species [3842].
- Raise public awareness to promote conservation actions: No studies were found evaluating effects on butterflies and moths [3847].
- Legally protect butterflies and moths: No studies were found evaluating effects [3863].

question_details.query: How do different methods of harvesting timber, such as selective logging and shelterwood harvesting, compare to clearcutting in their impact on moth diversity in US forests?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In US forests, shelterwood harvesting was associated with higher macro‑moth species richness than clearcutting or patch‑cutting, with richness similar to thinned and unharvested stands in one controlled, before‑after study; two replicated, controlled, before‑after studies found moth richness under shelterwood was similar to single‑tree and group‑selection harvesting or clearcutting but recovered faster after shelterwood than after group selection or clearcutting, while remaining lower than in unharvested forest (3871). For selective (single‑tree) logging, a replicated, controlled, before‑after US study found moth species richness was similar to group selection and clearcutting, but lower than in unharvested forest (3867). For group selection and thinning, one controlled, before‑after US study found thinning produced higher macro‑moth richness than patch‑cutting or clearcutting and similar richness to unharvested forest; two replicated, controlled, before‑after studies found group selection had moth richness similar to single‑tree selection and clearcutting, with richness recovering at a similar rate to clearcutting and slower than shelterwood (3868, 3871).

question_details.query: What are the effects on butterflies and moths of different methods for managing linear features like road verges and power lines?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across power-line corridors, mechanical cutting and recent scrub/tree clearance were associated with higher butterfly species richness than unmanaged land, with richness highest 2–4 years post-clearance; abundance was higher than unmanaged in some cases, while time-since-management effects varied by species, and mowing versus cutting/herbicide produced similar abundances for several species except frosted elfin, which was higher with mowing; pearl-bordered fritillaries used areas cleared 1–2 years earlier but not ≥3 years earlier [3855]. On road verges and pavements, restricting or stopping herbicide use in restored roadside prairies was linked to greater butterfly richness and abundance and lower mortality risk than verges dominated by non-native grasses without restrictions; on transmission lines, unsprayed and unmown sites had similar butterfly richness but higher abundance of northern/pearl crescents than sprayed and mown sites, with similar total abundance [3899]. Altering mowing on greenspaces/road verges showed that less frequent or no mowing increased butterfly/moth richness and diversity; unmown parks and road verges/under power lines had higher abundance for all adult butterflies or for pearl/northern pearl crescents, while other species showed similar abundance; late-summer roadside mowing had more ringlets than mid-summer; less frequent or later mowing reduced numbers of butterflies killed by traffic; butterflies were recorded on verges mown once or twice a year and on unmown verges, but on mown verges they were only recorded where hay was removed [3841]. Restoring or maintaining species-rich grassland along verges (e.g., sowing native wildflowers, increasing larval host plants, plant species richness, and flowering plants) increased richness and sometimes abundance of butterflies, day-flying and burnet moths compared to non-native dominated verges; wider verges had higher richness and abundance; in Canada, mown or unmown verges and power-line sites had similar richness and abundance to remnant prairies; mortality risk was lower on restored prairie verges than non-native grass verges, but more dead butterflies/moths occurred on roads with tall meadow verges and with habitat in the central reservation; less frequent or later mowing reduced roadkill; monarch parasite loads on mown verge milkweed were similar to prairies [3854]. Planting road verges with appropriate native species was associated in some studies with higher richness of butterfly/moth adults and caterpillars than verges with mixed or non-native plants, though other studies found similar adult richness, and effects on abundance were mixed [3842].

question_details.query: What are the documented effects of excluding different types of herbivores on butterfly and moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- A replicated, site comparison study in the UK found higher density of pearl-bordered fritillary at sites fenced to exclude grazing animals than at unfenced sites [3885].
- Across ten studies on excluding vertebrate herbivores: two of four replicated studies reported greater species richness of butterflies and macro-moths in forest plots fenced to exclude or reduce non-native pigs and deer, while two studies of elk exclusion showed mixed effects on richness depending on fire intensity and year; grassland plots fenced to exclude elk had similar butterfly richness to unfenced plots; a global systematic review found no effect of reducing/removing grazing or browsing on butterfly and moth species richness in temperate and boreal forests [3891].
- For abundance, five of eight studies reported higher abundance of butterflies, moths, caterpillars, rare macro‑moths, or New Forest burnet moths in plots fenced to exclude or reduce deer, sheep, pigs, or large herbivores (one of these also found similar total macro‑moth abundance between treatments); two elk-exclosure studies reported mixed effects by fire intensity and year, with grassland elk exclosures showing similar butterfly abundance; a forest fenced to exclude sika deer had similar overall moth abundance but lower tree‑feeding moth abundance; a global systematic review reported increased abundance of butterflies and moths when grazing/browsing was reduced or removed [3891].
- In a paired, controlled study in the Netherlands, Glanville fritillary caterpillar nests had higher survival (100% vs 88%) and less damage in grassland fenced to exclude sheep than in a grazed area [3891].

question_details.query: In agricultural landscapes, how does restoring grassland from arable land compare to restoring grassland from abandoned meadows for butterfly communities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Restoring arable land to permanent grassland: Butterfly communities on grasslands seeded from bare soil became increasingly similar to existing high-quality grasslands over the first 10 years after establishment, and older sown grasslands using competitive mixes had a greater proportion of specialist butterflies than newer grasslands sown with less competitive species that required periodic re-seeding (3929). Species richness of butterflies and moths was higher on 4–5-year-old created grasslands and abandoned cropland than on conventionally managed grassland or cultivated farms, and richness and abundance were higher when seed mixes included forbs compared to grass-only mixes; abundance on restored grassland was similar to semi-natural grasslands and higher than in crop fields, though abundance did not increase with time since restoration; after adopting a scheme including arable reversion, abundance of several butterfly species and large moths increased on a farm (3929). Restoring semi-natural grassland from abandoned meadows (via scrub clearance and reintroduction of grazing or mowing): Restored sites had butterfly communities different from existing species-rich grasslands and did not become more similar over time (3955). Species richness was similar to, or lower than, unrestored or continuously managed grassland depending on study (3955). Abundance was often lower than on unmanaged, abandoned grasslands for many species, though some species had higher abundance on restored grasslands than on continuously grazed sites; in other cases, abundance on restored sites was similar to unmanaged or continuously managed grasslands; in one case, egg density of blue-spot hairstreak was higher on scrub-cut restored grasslands than on unrestored or continuously managed grasslands (3955).

question_details.query: What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of restoring different types of wetland habitats, such as peatlands and floodplains, for butterfly conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across wetlands and floodplains, evidence from three studies reports mixed outcomes: created/restored wetlands had higher macroinvertebrate diversity (including butterflies and moths), with richness increasing with wetland age and reaching levels similar to mature ponds; a restored wetland prairie had higher great copper egg abundance and greater adult use than degraded prairie, but egg and caterpillar survival was lower in annually flooded, seed-mix restorations compared to degraded sites [3949]. In managed fens, mowing was associated with greater butterfly species richness than cattle grazing, whereas recent cutting (including autumn/winter cuts) reduced large copper egg numbers and caterpillar survival compared to uncut fens [3950]. In peatlands, restoration (e.g., re-wetting, raising water tables, tree removal, ditch blocking) increased species richness and abundance of mire specialist butterflies to levels comparable with pristine sites in some studies, and shifted moth communities toward an intermediate state between drained and pristine mires; however, moth abundance responses were mixed by species, large heath caterpillars had lower winter survival where water levels had risen, and Alcon large blue occupancy was lower on recently re-wetted wet heathland [3948]. For creating scrapes and pools, no studies directly evaluated effects on butterflies or moths [3951].

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of using prescribed fire in forest ecosystems for butterfly and moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In coniferous forests in the USA, sites restored 1–2 years after burning (in combination with thinning) or burned once within the last 20 years had higher butterfly species richness than unburned forest [3877]. In pine forests in the USA, sites restored 1–2 years after burning (in combination with thinning) had higher butterfly abundance than unburned forest [3877]. In mixed forest and shrubland in the USA, sites burned the previous year had similar butterfly species richness to unburned sites [3877]. In eucalyptus forest in Australia, the spring after selective burning had fewer Eltham copper caterpillars than before [3877].

question_details.query: What conservation actions can be implemented in urban environments to support butterfly and moth populations?
How do different methods of creating field margins in European farmland, such as uncultivated strips versus sown wildflower strips, compare in their effectiveness for butterfly communities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across European studies, sown wildflower strips generally support higher butterfly species richness and abundance than unsown or conventional margins, including in the UK, Switzerland, Finland and Germany [3932]. Uncultivated margins frequently have lower richness and abundance than margins sown with grasses and forbs or wildflowers, though some studies report similar richness, and permanent uncultivated margins can exceed sown fallows; within uncultivated margins, wider/longer strips, proximity to existing grassland, and avoiding summer cutting are associated with higher richness and/or abundance [3981]. Floristically enhanced or wildflower-sown grass margins tend to have greater butterfly richness and abundance than standard grass or uncultivated margins; in Sweden, margins sown with legumes or clover–grass ley had higher richness and abundance than uncultivated margins [3982].

question_details.query: What are the observed effects of ceasing grassland management, either by stopping mowing or grazing, on butterfly abundance and diversity?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, ceasing mowing or grazing produced mixed outcomes for butterflies and moths. Community composition sometimes remained similar to managed sites, but after abandonment the community became dominated by generalist species with fewer generations per year (3957, 3956). For diversity, after stopping mowing, five of seven studies reported similar species richness to managed grasslands, with some cases of lower richness after 6–13 years or >50 years, and one case of higher richness when meadows were left uncut all summer (3957). After stopping grazing, six of nine studies reported similar richness to grazed sites, one found greater richness than sheep-grazed grassland, two found lower richness after >5–20 years or many years, one found higher richness where grazing ceased 2–9 years ago than in >10-year abandonments or currently grazed, and three studies reported higher richness in grasslands abandoned 4, 5–10 or >10 years compared to extensively or commercially grazed, with similarity to lightly grazed in two cases (3956). For abundance, stopping mowing led to lower abundance in some studies, higher abundance in others, species-specific or habitat-shifted responses (woodland/hedgerow species increasing, grassland/farmland species decreasing), local extinctions in some cases (e.g., silver-studded blue), mixed species responses across regions, and time-since-abandonment effects (e.g., similar abundance after ~6 years but lower after >25 years with no caterpillars) (3957). After stopping grazing, six of 20 studies found higher abundance than grazed (sometimes only vs intensive grazing), four found lower, four found similar, four reported species-specific mixed responses, one found density higher 2–9 years post-cessation than in >10-year abandonments or currently grazed, local extinctions occurred for large blue and silver-studded blue in some meadows, species-specific responses included clouded Apollo being lower than lightly grazed but higher than heavily grazed, and one European review reported benefits for six of 67 species of conservation concern (3956).

question_details.query: What are the alternatives to using prescribed fire for maintaining disturbance in forest habitats for the benefit of butterflies and moths?
What is the state of the evidence regarding the success of restoring habitats after mining and quarrying activities for butterfly and moth conservation?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Four studies (two in the Czech Republic, one in the UK, one in New Zealand) assessed restoring or creating habitats after mining/quarrying for butterflies and moths, with mixed outcomes (3862). Community composition: a replicated, paired, site comparison in the Czech Republic found 15% of 380 invertebrate species (including 208 moth species) occurred only on flattened spoil heaps, while 30% occurred only on unflattened heaps (3862). Richness/diversity: replicated, paired, site comparisons in the Czech Republic found technically restored quarries had lower species richness of butterflies and day‑flying moths than quarries left to restore naturally, and flattened spoil heaps had lower moth species richness than unflattened spoil heaps (3862). Population response: a replicated, randomized, controlled UK study on slate waste tips found fertilizer application on trees did not change caterpillar abundance compared to unfertilized trees, and a New Zealand site comparison found a peat bog restored after mining supported similar density and caterpillar size of the Fred the thread moth to undisturbed bogs (3862). No behaviour studies were reported (3862).

question_details.query: Over what timescales have butterfly populations been observed to respond to woodland management practices like coppicing and clearing in the UK?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In UK studies of cleared woodland patches, heath fritillary abundance was higher in areas cleared 2–4 years earlier than in patches cleared 7–11 years earlier or in the first year after clearance [3938]. In UK coppiced woodlands (with additional evidence from France and Germany), higher butterfly abundance has been recorded in stands coppiced two, two–four, five–seven or 12–15 years earlier compared to stands coppiced 5–11 or more than 15 years earlier, and one study reported greater butterfly species richness in woodland coppiced two years earlier than in woodland coppiced more than 15 years earlier [3939].

question_details.query: What are the most effective methods for reducing grazing intensity on grasslands to benefit butterfly populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies several ways to reduce grazing intensity and associated outcomes for butterflies and moths: (1) Reducing stocking density of livestock was associated with higher species richness and/or abundance of adult butterflies, moths and burnet moths in multiple replicated studies across several countries, though some studies recorded similar richness or abundance at low vs. high densities and effects on caterpillars were mixed (3959). (2) Seasonally removing livestock (e.g., removing cattle in summer, not grazing silage fields in September, removing sheep in winter or during peak flowering) increased butterfly and caterpillar abundance in several replicated, controlled UK studies, while other studies found similar richness or abundance compared to continuous grazing (3960). (3) Using rotational grazing sometimes resulted in greater butterfly and burnet moth species richness and/or abundance than continuous grazing, including cases where rotational systems outperformed continuous grazing at higher stocking densities, though other studies found similar or mixed responses among species (3965). (4) Delaying cutting or first grazing dates (e.g., grazing commencing after mid‑June, cutting in July/September rather than May/June) was associated with higher abundance of butterflies, burnet moths and caterpillars in several studies, and one study reported higher abundance of clouded Apollo where grazing started after 15 June alongside lower stocking density (3967). For context, increasing grazing intensity generally reduced butterfly and moth richness or abundance relative to low or no grazing in multiple studies (3962).

question_details.query: How does managing semi-natural open habitats with rough grazing compare to using prescribed fire for butterfly and moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Rough grazing in semi-natural habitats: Across nine studies, species richness was often similar to unmanaged or cut areas in calcareous dunes and shrubsteppe, while light sheep grazing on saltmarsh increased micro-moth species richness compared to moderate/heavy grazing and was similar to ungrazed marsh; upland rough grassland under livestock grazing had higher butterfly richness than improved grassland (3944). Abundance responses were mixed: higher abundance for large copper eggs and some butterfly species under cattle/pony grazing in fens and dunes, similar abundance to ungrazed in shrubsteppe, lower abundance in meadow steppe under livestock, and on saltmarsh light grazing increased total micro-moth abundance and some caterpillars compared to moderate/heavy grazing or ungrazed, though other caterpillars were lower under grazing than ungrazed; upland rough grassland had higher butterfly abundance than improved grassland (3944). Occupancy/use: brown argus and Alcon large blue were more likely to occupy grazed calcareous dunes and heathland than unmanaged or differently managed sites (3944). Prescribed fire in open habitats: Species richness of butterflies was often similar between burned and unburned shrubland plots and field margins; patch-burning in pastures yielded lower richness than rotational grazing, similar to some grazed/mown pastures, and higher than continuous grazing (3882). Abundance responses were mixed: increased abundance for heath fritillary adults, marsh fritillary caterpillar webs, and Fender’s blue caterpillars/eggs one or more years after burning compared to before or to unburned/grazed land, but decreased abundance for Brenton blue eggs/adults, rosy marsh moth caterpillars, and regal fritillary on burned sites versus unburned; some species (e.g., regal fritillary, arogos skipper) were less abundant on burned prairies than hayed/grazed, while generalists and some species (e.g., purplish copper) were more abundant on burned than hayed/grazed; one review reported occasional grassland burning benefitted 10/67 species of conservation concern (3882). Survival/occupancy: Fender’s blue caterpillar survival was lower one year post-burn than in unburned plots, while marsh fritillary occupancy of fen meadows was similar among burned, grazed, and unmanaged sites (3882). Overall, both approaches showed mixed, species- and context-dependent effects on richness, abundance, survival, and occupancy across studies (3944, 3882).

question_details.query: What are the effects of managing traditional perennial crops like orchards, vineyards, and coffee plantations to benefit butterflies and moths?
What are the benefits for butterflies of maintaining species-rich, semi-natural grasslands compared to using set-aside in European agricultural landscapes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two replicated, site comparison studies in Germany and Hungary found that old meadows mown in July and lightly grazed or annually mown meadows had a higher species richness of adult butterflies and caterpillars than recently established set-aside or cereal crops [3908]. Across European studies (Germany, Ireland, Hungary, Finland), sown or naturally regenerating set-aside sometimes had greater butterfly and day-flying moth species richness than cereal fields or pasture, and in some cases higher butterfly abundance than cereal fields, particularly when sown with less competitive grasses; however, multiple studies also found fallow or stubble set-aside often had similar butterfly abundance to arable fields and pasture, and similar abundance to uncultivated field boundaries or extensively farmed land (UK, Switzerland) [3980].

question_details.query: For butterfly conservation in European farmland, how do wildflower strips compare to uncultivated or grass margins?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple European studies, sown wildflower strips generally support higher butterfly species richness and diversity than conventional field margins, unsown margins, cropped fields, or conventional grassland, and higher abundance of all, generalist, and specialist butterflies than these alternatives [3932]. Field margins sown with wildflowers also show greater richness and abundance of butterflies than grass‑only margins, and floristically enhanced grass buffers or wildflower strips outperform standard grass margins for both richness and abundance [3932; 3982]. In contrast, uncultivated margins often have lower butterfly richness and abundance than margins sown with grasses and forbs or with wildflowers, whereas wider or less‑cut uncultivated margins can fare better but still typically underperform compared to sown options [3981]. Some studies reported similar richness or abundance between wildflower strips and other margin types or habitats in certain comparisons or years [3932; 3981].

question_details.query: What are the effects of removing or excluding problematic plant and animal species on butterfly and moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Removing, controlling, or excluding invertebrate herbivores: One replicated, site comparison study in the UK reported higher density of pearl-bordered fritillary at sites fenced to exclude grazing animals than at unfenced sites [3885]. Removing, controlling, or excluding native predators: Across five studies in the UK, USA, and Kenya, predator exclusion (e.g., mesh cages, net sleeves, sticky resin) increased survival of large copper caterpillars, Boisduval silkworm eggs and caterpillars, and Appalachian brown eggs and juveniles, while two studies found no increase in monarch caterpillar survival after excluding vertebrate or terrestrial predators (mainly ants) [3889]. Removing, controlling, or excluding vertebrate herbivores: Studies from multiple countries and a global review found that fencing to exclude or reduce densities of deer, sheep, pigs, and large herbivores sometimes increased butterfly and macro-moth species richness, with mixed effects when excluding elk, and the global review found no effect on richness in temperate and boreal forests; abundance was often higher in fenced plots, though effects were mixed with elk, overall moth abundance was similar but tree-feeding moth abundance lower in sika deer–excluded forest, and a global review found increased abundance when grazing/browsing was reduced; in the Netherlands, all Glanville fritillary caterpillar nests survived and fewer nests were damaged in sheep-excluded grassland compared to grazed areas [3891]. Removing or controlling non-native or problematic plants: Two studies (Mauritius, USA) reported higher butterfly species richness after invasive plant removal (in one case alongside fencing), while several studies found higher abundance of specific butterflies (e.g., Apollo, Fender’s blue eggs) or total butterflies after removing or cutting invasive plants; other studies reported similar abundance or use compared to untreated or uninvaded sites, one case recorded fewer Brenton blue eggs after bracken removal following burning, survival of Columbia silvery blue was similar with herbicide application, and one herbicide reduced snowberry checkerspot survival while two others had no effect; invasive plant removal increased habitat use by Fender’s blue and frosted elfin in some cases, with no change for Columbia silvery blue [3890]. Removing or controlling non-native predators: No studies were found evaluating effects on butterflies and moths [3884].

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the effects of restoring post-industrial sites, like mines or brownfields, on butterfly and moth communities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of protecting or restoring brownfield or ex‑industrial sites on butterflies and moths [3835]. Four studies evaluated restoring or creating habitats after mining and quarrying, with two in the Czech Republic and one each in the UK and New Zealand [3862]. In the Czech Republic, 15% of 380 invertebrate species (including 208 moth species) were only found on flattened spoil heaps, while 30% were only found on unflattened heaps [3862]. In the Czech Republic, technically restored quarries had lower species richness of butterflies and day‑flying moths than quarries left to restore naturally [3862]. In the Czech Republic, flattened spoil heaps had lower moth species richness than unflattened spoil heaps [3862]. In the UK, on slate waste tips, trees with fertilizer applied had a similar abundance of caterpillars to unfertilized trees [3862]. In New Zealand, a peat bog restored after mining supported a similar density and size of Fred the thread moth caterpillars compared to undisturbed bogs [3862].

question_details.query: What factors influence the success of captive breeding and release programs for butterflies and moths?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence indicates multiple factors can influence outcomes of captive breeding and release or translocation programs for butterflies and moths: (1) Management at release sites, including coppicing, selective felling, planting, fencing, host plant translocation, invasive plant removal, sheep grazing, scrub clearance or unspecified habitat restoration conducted before or after release, was reported alongside populations that persisted and increased in abundance following translocation in multiple cases (3909), and some releases occurred into managed habitat (3914). (2) Population persistence often required continued interventions such as captive-rearing of wild-laid caterpillars or supplementation by further releases (3914). (3) Survival and persistence varied with source and approach: translocated large copper caterpillars had higher survival than released, captive-bred caterpillars (3909), and released captive-bred large copper caterpillars had lower survival than captive, wild or translocated caterpillars (3914). (4) Life stage and context of release varied (eggs, caterpillars, pupae, adults), with reports of populations persisting 2–28 years in some cases, while others died out within 0–12 years or required further releases (3914; 3909). (5) Captive-rearing conditions affected survival and condition, including lower density improving survival, temperature (20 °C higher survival than 25 °C), ant colony context for myrmecophilous species (higher survival without queens or with winged females present), differences among ant species and among host plant species, and the origin of ants (from sites where parasitic butterfly species occur) influencing survival (3916). (6) Overwintering method during captive rearing influenced survival (lower in refrigerators than in environmental chambers or outside) (3916). (7) Diet and symbiont availability during captive rearing affected development and adult condition, including plant species provided and access to appropriate ant colonies (3916). (8) Long-term captivity influenced traits, with captive lines showing differences in body size and wing size, and differences in fecundity relative to more recently captive lines (3916). (9) Placement of parasitic blue butterflies into specific ant nests without queens improved caterpillar survival during translocation (3909). (10) Genetic considerations were noted, with a translocated population showing similar genetic diversity to its source after 19 years (3909). (11) There is no direct evidence evaluating the introduction of mated females to increase genetic diversity for butterflies and moths (3912).

question_details.query: To benefit butterflies on productive grasslands, how does reducing livestock density compare with seasonal livestock removal or reducing mowing frequency?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Reducing livestock density: Across replicated and site-comparison studies, lower stocking densities were associated with greater species richness in 5/8 studies and greater abundance in 8/11 studies, though some studies reported similar richness/abundance and one found lower richness in one year; survival of Glanville fritillary nests was similar between low and high densities, and early nest damage was lower under low density but not after two months (3959). Seasonal livestock removal: Two of three studies found similar butterfly species richness to continuous grazing, while one found higher richness; three controlled studies found higher butterfly/caterpillar abundance with seasonal removal, while three replicated controlled/site-comparison studies found similar abundance; a European review reported that reducing grazing intensity benefitted 41/67 butterfly species but did not distinguish between seasonal removal and reduced density (3960). Reducing mowing frequency: Two of three studies found higher butterfly/moth species richness with once-per-year cutting than with more frequent cutting, while one found similar richness; three of five studies found similar butterfly abundance between once-per-year and more frequent cutting, whereas two studies found higher abundance with occasional or once-per-year cutting (3961).

question_details.query: What are the benefits of planting new hedges and managing existing ones for butterfly and moth conservation on farmland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, established hedgerows were associated with higher species richness of butterflies and macro‑moths than in‑field beetle banks, crops or pasture, though richness was sometimes similar to grass banks between fields [3976]. Hedgerows also supported higher abundances of butterflies, moths/macro‑moths and gatekeepers than beetle banks, grass margins without hedgerows, field interiors, or locations 5–10 m from hedgerows, while one study found similar abundance to grass banks between fields [3976]. Moths recorded close to hedgerows were more likely to fly parallel to them than moths further away [3976]. Within planted hedgerows, gorse, oak and blackthorn hosted more species of arthropods, including caterpillars, than commonly planted hawthorn [3976]. Managing existing hedgerows to increase structural complexity or include trees was linked to higher species richness or diversity of butterflies and macro‑moths than simpler hedgerows without trees [3975]. Cutting regimes that allow incremental growth, cutting once every 2–3 years, or autumn cutting were associated with higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths, moth caterpillars and pupae, and more brown hairstreak eggs than annual, same‑size cutting, although in some cases caterpillar/pupa abundance was similar between regimes [3975]. Hedgerows kept 1–2 m tall had higher butterfly species richness than those kept below 1 m, while one study reported more adult butterflies in hedgerows maintained below 1 m; fields with larger‑volume hedgerows showed higher butterfly richness and abundance in one of two years [3975]. Hedgerows with trees or more complex structure had higher abundance of butterflies and pale shining brown moths, though some studies found similar total macro‑moth abundance with or without trees [3975]. Scalloped hedgerow edges supported more brown hairstreak eggs than straight edges, and field margins next to hedgerow trees had higher abundance of most shrub‑/tree‑feeding moth species than margins away from trees [3975]. Laid or coppiced hedgerows had higher butterfly abundance than unmanaged hedgerows, but one study found managed hedgerows had lower caterpillar abundance than remnant hedgerows [3975].

question_details.query: What are the overall effects on butterfly and moth communities of creating uncropped habitat areas like set-asides and beetle banks within farmland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies, set-aside fields often supported greater species richness of butterflies and day-flying moths than cereal or pasture fields, particularly when sown with less competitive grasses; however, some studies found similar richness to arable or pasture fields, and richness sometimes did not differ among 1–3-year-old set-asides; butterfly communities in older set-asides also included species that were less migratory, had longer larval periods, and fewer generations per year than those in newer set-asides [3980]. Abundances in set-asides were sometimes higher than in cereal fields (especially in second-year or less-competitive grass mixes) but were frequently similar to arable fields, pasture, uncultivated field boundaries, or extensively farmed land; in one USA study, abundance was similar to native prairie in year one but lower thereafter [3980]. Beetle banks had higher richness and abundance of micro‑moths than conventionally managed field margins, similar richness and abundance of macro‑moths, similar caterpillar abundance to field margins and crop fields, and lower adult butterfly richness and abundance than along hedgerows [3927]. Grass buffer strips/margins sometimes increased butterfly species richness over cropped edges, with wider or floristically enhanced margins generally showing higher richness or diversity of butterflies and moths, though several studies reported similar richness to standard margins or cropped edges; butterfly abundance was often higher on grass margins than cropped edges, with wider or floristically enhanced margins increasing abundance of habitat‑sensitive butterflies and some moth groups, though responses were mixed across taxa and studies; caterpillar abundance on grass margins was similar to that on beetle banks [3982, 3927].

question_details.query: What are the potential benefits and negative consequences of abandoning management on grasslands for butterfly and moth populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies of ceasing grazing or mowing on grasslands, community composition of butterflies and moths was often similar to managed sites, but after 6 years of abandonment communities became dominated by generalist species with fewer generations per year [3956][3957]. Species richness frequently remained similar to managed grasslands, sometimes increased after 4–10 years of abandonment or when meadows were left uncut for a summer, but was often lower after longer periods (e.g., >10–20 years or >50 years) or compared to traditional rotational mowing and burning [3956][3957]. Abundance responses were mixed: in some cases abandonment (from weeks to 25 years) increased total butterflies, day‑flying or nocturnal moths, Scotch argus, caterpillars, and small insects, and uncut or temporarily abandoned meadows had higher abundances than annually or frequently mown sites [3956][3957]. In other cases, abandonment for 1–20 years reduced overall butterflies or some species and caterpillars relative to mowing once or twice per year, with some time‑since‑abandonment effects (e.g., higher densities 2–9 years after cessation than >10 years or currently grazed) and species‑specific mixed responses [3956][3957]. Abandonment tended to increase woodland and hedgerow butterflies and burnet moths, but decrease grassland or farmland species, and extinctions of large blue and silver‑studded blue occurred in some abandoned meadows; heath fritillary abundance was similar around six years post‑abandonment but lower with no caterpillars after >25 years [3956][3957]. Behavioural/use responses included similar occurrence of hoary bell moth caterpillars and similar frequency of marsh fritillary webs in abandoned vs managed sites, but reduced occurrence of grizzled skipper and painted lady and increased occurrence of small pearl‑bordered fritillary in abandoned meadows [3956][3957].

question_details.query: What are the typical timeframes for butterfly and moth population responses following forest management interventions like clearing, coppicing, and thinning?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Clearing/opening patches: In one study, butterfly abundance and species richness declined over the first three years after clearing, though cleared patches supported higher butterfly abundance than unmanaged or coppiced areas in some cases (3938). In the UK, heath fritillary abundance was greater 2–4 years after clearance than in the first year or 7–11 years after clearance (3938). Thinning: Across multiple studies, one, two or four years after thinning (often combined with burning, mulching or nearby felling), butterfly abundance and species richness were higher than before management or in unmanaged woodland (3940). Coppicing: Butterfly species richness was greater two years after coppicing than in areas coppiced >15 years ago (3939). Butterfly abundance was higher in woodland coppiced two, two–four, five–seven or 12–15 years ago than in woodland coppiced 5–11 or >15 years ago (3939). For moths, abundance was similar in woodland coppiced 1–4, 5–8 and 12–20 years ago, and macro-moth abundance was lower in coppiced woodland than in mature forest with no change across coppice ages (3939).

question_details.query: In European forests, how do the effects of coppicing and clearing patches compare for butterfly and moth communities?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across European forests, both coppicing and clearing patches tend to increase butterfly metrics but often reduce macro‑moth metrics compared to mature or unmanaged woodland. Coppiced sites frequently had higher butterfly species richness and abundance (including heath fritillary), with different-aged coppice supporting different moth and butterfly communities, while macro‑moths were less species‑rich and less abundant than in mature forest [3939]. Cleared or opened patches generally had higher butterfly species richness and abundance than unmanaged or closed‑canopy forest, especially in larger clearings, but showed lower macro‑moth species richness (and, on wider rides, lower macro‑moth abundance) than mature forest; butterfly richness and abundance could decline in the first three years after clearing [3938].

question_details.query: What is the evidence for the success of re-establishing butterfly populations through translocation and captive-breeding programs?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across 16 studies of translocations within former range, many translocated butterfly and moth populations persisted 2–12 years and increased in abundance, though others died out within 0–7 years; a review found 25% of translocated/released captive-bred butterfly populations survived ≥3 years, 38% died out within 3 years, and only 8% were known to survive >10 years; in some cases, translocated populations persisted up to decades but ultimately died out or needed supplementation; survival of translocated large copper caterpillars exceeded that of released captive-bred caterpillars; and a reintroduced large blue population retained genetic diversity similar to its source after 19 years (all from 3909). For releases of captive-bred individuals (13 studies), several populations persisted 2–28 years and increased (sometimes with continued rearing or supplementary releases), but others died out within 1–12 years or required further releases; in one replicated study, 3/10 released barberry carpet moth populations established, and at least one persisted 5 years; a review across the UK and Ireland reported 25% of captive-bred/translocated populations survived >3 years, 38% died out within that time, and only 8% were known to survive >10 years; and multiple studies found released captive-bred large copper caterpillars had lower survival than captive, wild, or translocated caterpillars (all from 3914). Translocations outside known range (4 studies) showed mixed outcomes: two studies reported populations (including one involving captive-bred individuals) that persisted and increased over 8 and 28 years, while another died out within one year; a long-established introduced population maintained genetic diversity comparable to its source (all from 3911).

question_details.query: What are the most effective ways to manage field margins in arable landscapes for increasing butterfly abundance?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Planting wildflower/nectar flower strips in field margins was associated with higher abundance of all butterflies, generalist and specialist butterflies, and meadow brown compared to conventional or unsown margins, cropped fields/margins, and conventional grassland; margins sown with wildflowers also had higher butterfly abundance than grass-only field margins; farms with wildflower strips had higher abundance of butterflies and micro-moths than conventionally managed farms; plots sown with lucerne had higher butterfly abundance than plots sown with borage, chicory or sainfoin [3932].
- In uncultivated margins, butterfly abundance was often lower than in sown margins, but margins that were not cut, or only cut in spring/autumn, had higher butterfly abundance than margins cut in summer; wider margins had higher butterfly abundance than conventional-width margins; margins located closer to existing grassland had higher butterfly and burnet moth abundance; uncultivated margins had higher abundance of butterflies and day-flying moths than cereal fields or cropped field edges [3981].
- Leaving uncropped, cultivated margins/plots: fields with wider margins between crops had higher butterfly abundance in one of two years; farms under agri-environment schemes (including uncropped cultivated margins) had higher abundance of butterflies and micro-moths than conventionally managed farms; farms with enhanced agri-environment options (including uncropped, cultivated margins) had higher abundance of some butterflies but lower abundance of others than simpler schemes [3923].

question_details.query: How does the scale of habitat features, such as field size and margin width, affect butterfly and moth communities on farmland?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across five studies, landscapes and farms with smaller fields had higher butterfly and burnet moth abundance, and in some cases higher species richness, than areas with larger fields; two replicated site comparisons found higher richness with smaller fields, two found similar richness, and a before-and-after study found richness increased after reducing field size alongside more edges and margins (3974). Fifteen studies on grass margins reported that wider margins (up to 6 m) often supported greater species richness or diversity of butterflies, macro‑moths and micro‑moths than narrower or conventional margins, though one study found macro‑moth richness similar between wide and conventional margins (3982). Seven site comparison studies (including paired designs) found wider grass margins (up to 6 m) had higher abundance of habitat‑sensitive butterflies, macro‑moths and micro‑moths than narrower or conventional margins, while other studies found similar abundance for disturbance‑tolerant butterflies and some moth groups (3982). Replicated controlled studies showed grass margins, compared to cropped edges, often had higher butterfly abundance and sometimes higher richness; however, one UK study found 2‑m margins increased butterfly richness over cropped edges while 6‑m margins did not (3982). A UK paired comparison found margins next to water bodies with restricted agrochemical use (and restricted mowing/grazing) had greater moth abundance but similar moth species richness than conventionally managed margins (3894). UK studies on beetle banks showed micro‑moth richness and abundance were higher on beetle banks and AES‑managed margins than on conventionally managed margins, while adult butterflies were less abundant and less species‑rich on beetle banks than along hedgerows; caterpillar abundance was similar between beetle banks and field margins or crop fields (3927). Some studies reported that floristically enhanced or wildflower‑sown margins/strips had higher butterfly richness and abundance than standard grass margins or cropped/unsown edges; in other cases richness or abundance was similar or mixed among butterfly and moth groups (3932, 3982).
